title: Will a Republican win the special election for Alabama's U.S. Senate seat?
preds: "Conventional wisdom is that "this is Alabama" so Moore will win, which is just too deterministic."
Senate race called. Doug Jones wins. The steady campaigning, spending and turnout was enough with the bad sentiment against Roy Moore.

Unofficial results from Alabama's official website for reporting election results.... After all "Counties Reported" (does this mean all precincts have reported?), turnout was more than 40% (high!!!!) (unheard of in a modern non-Presidential statewide election in Alabama?) and Jones' margin of victory was probably sufficiently large that diversion of Republican votes away from Moore to write-in candidates wouldn't've made the difference.
Jones	49.92%	671,151
Moore	48.38%	650,436
Write-In	1.69%	22,780
Total		1,344,367

this is what the race for that same senate seat looked like in 2014 when the dem raised less than $5k and Jeff Sessions ultimately ran unopposed (dark red >89.9% of vote, light red, > 79.9% of vote): 
https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4e/United_States_Senate_election_in_Alabama%2C_2014_results_by_county.svg
YAH so  I was right.  The turnout was low, black people voted.

I note that - at this moment, anyway - the number of write-in votes is significantly greater than Jones' margin of victory. I think the result of this fact will be that some Republicans will regard this election as "stolen" by treacherous RINOs who refused to vote for the party's candidate. The fact the Moore is a sleazeball and an ignoramus will be considered comparatively insignificant. 2018 should be interesting.

I originally predicted 50% - too close to call.  But now I think republican voters writing-in another candidate instead of voting for Moore is going to give Jones the win, plus Jones seems to be getting the high turnout among Democrats, especially young people and African Americans that people weren't sure he was actually going to be able to get.

Let me make this simple - Alabama voters will rally on two points - Moore hasn'r rec'd due process and therefore is seen as the aggrieved part, and Jones is pro abortion a litmus test item in the south. So they vote for a possible molester and a (as they see him) a known baby killer. Advantage Moore, on record turnout.
Bullish on Jones for a few reasons:
For me, too close to call. Polls are coming up with conflicting results, related to different elements of polling processes.
Still at 100% that Moore will win.

One does wish people would stop referring to elections as "races."  They are not races, nor any other sort of game, and using sport metaphors gives vast numbers of Americans the wrong idea about what is going on.  The important thing in an election is not who is ahead at any particular moment, but about what the winner will do once elected.   In any case, the good white Christians of Alabama will not vote for a Democrat, no matter who the Rs put up.  In the olden days of of the Solid South (which was solidly D, this being a moment in history when the Republican party was the less racialist), such voters were referred to as "yellow-dog" Democrats, of whom it was said they would vote for a yellow dog on the Democratic ticket rather than any Republican.  The party has changed, but the principle hasn't.
[edit2]: Alabama Supreme Court just ruled the Secretary of State does not need to retain digital ballot images, which can be used to prove/disprove fraud.

Today the state votes to fill the Senate seat left vacant when Donald Trump appointed as attorney-general Jeff Sessions, who had held it for 20 years. Alabama is deeply Republican—Mr Trump won it by 28 points, and no Democrat has been elected senator for 25 years—but this race is too close to call, largely because the Republican nominee is Roy Moore. He believes homosexuality should be illegal, Muslims should be barred from serving in Congress and the constitution exists to foster Christianity. Several women have accused him of offences, which he denies, ranging from sexual harassment to assault; most were teenagers at the time of the alleged incidents. Doug Jones, the Democrat, is a genial former federal prosecutor whose scrappy campaign caught fire. Mr Moore retains strong support among white evangelicals, around half of Alabama’s electorate. To win, Mr Jones needs strong African-American turnout, and votes from Republican business-owners rightly worried about the state’s reputation

Psychology has shown that it is difficult to pry oneself away from the political views of their own political party.  I don't think that there are enough Alabamians willing to make the switch to Jones.  I understand that this prediction is completely subjective and lacks any quantitative analysis; but this race has been so close that I think the "tie" will go in Moore's favor.
Roy Moore is probably going to the United States Senate. The median of 6 polls in the last 7 days is Moore up by 4.5 points.
I seriously hope that I'm wrong on this. I'd much rather blow up my Brier score than be right in this case.

Running a naive aggregate, of the last 15 surveys, including the more traditional Fox News poll and the Online Survey Monkey poll, I'm coming up with 48% of the vote going to Roy Moore (R) and 45% of the vote going to Doug Jones (D), the margin of error at 98% confidence interval being 0.09% (Sample size is 20000).
Some of the things I'm considering/revisiting on the day before the election:
I am giving live interview polls more credence than robocalls.
saw a recent foxnews poll that projected a 10-point lead for the Democratic candidate, Jones.

New fox news and Monmouth polls have Jones up and tied respectively. Avg on real clear politics is 2.2 for Moore. High degree of uncertainty based on who will turn out so give slight edge to Moore based on being up in polling average and the default favorite based on being the Republican

OUTER VIEW 
I reviewed the  Real Clear Politics Polls from October thru today, paying particular attention to the margins of error (MOE). I discounted polls for which the MOE overlapped indicating no clear winner.  Then I calculated  weighted average proportions from the remaining polls (Non-overlapping) and had Moore 49%, Jones 43%, Undecided 6%.

I think with the outsized campaign spending  over the last month or so (10.2 -1.8 million) by Doug Jones and the fact that he has been on the campaign trail aggressively for the last 14 days while Roy Moore has not, puts Doug  Jones in the box seat. The difference will be voter turnout. A higher than average Republican turnout will be necessary. Are they energized or disillusioned with Moore? Roy Moore is staying closer to his base while Doug Jones is pushing his boundaries, by crisscrossing Alabama. My base rate for spending favoring a candidate is 86%. When I factor in voter turnout or non-turnout, the numbers move to democratic support shows a high voter turnout. I think it may be enough to have a Doug Jones victory. Also the base Roy Moore (60+ years) may be dwarfed by the surge in African American support for Doug Jones (450-550 Moore) to (600 -700) Jones. If the turn out is high, then its tight for Moore.
Reverting to original forecast based on Fox News survey
Removing emotion from this prediction, I think that Roy Moore will win this thing.
Not enough Republicans are willing to vote for a Democrat despite the pedophilia.  The evangelicals see abortion as more serious.

Shifting a little higher but staying below the consensus because Jones remains a normal polling error away from winning.

I listened to an interview on NPR this morning (12-6-2017) with a Republican strategist and he thought it was dead even and a lose-lose for Republicans.  He didn't think it possible to vote for a Democrat so recommended a write in candidate.  This will take potential winning votes away from Moore.  I also read another article which talked about signs in yards that said, GOP for Moore.  The passed tax cut is very unpopular with voters, even more so than the ACA.  A combination of factors is working against the Republican candidate for the Senate.  Anybody's race.

RCP average has Moore +2.3.  Easily take away 2% from Moore for "likely voters" in surveys who ways they will vote but stay home on the Republican side out of disgust with Moore.  Easily give Jones 2% extra for democratic surge voting (which we've seen in VA gov. race and almost every special this year).  That puts Jones up by about two points.  This is way overvalued right now.  65-35 for Jones.
Soul-searching time for Alabamians. What is right and wrong, good and evil?

Oh, and lest we forget, it's Alabama.

To mash-up this question with another that many of us are forecasting, I think if the Supreme Court finds against Masterpiece Cakeshop, you will see Moore's poll numbers rise. If the Republicans can once again shift the focus to the composition of the Supreme Court, their voters will probably fall into place and vote to keep a Republican majority in the Senate.

Real Clear Politics currently has Moore down by less than 1 point with around 7% undecided.  He originally had a 6 point lead before the sexual assault incident.  I'm guessing that as the incident moves further into the background, given the strongly republican leaning make up of the state, many of the undecided will break toward Moore.  The most recent poll already showed Moore up 2 points

The most recent polls https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/is-roy-moore-losing/ are showing a clear erosion of support for Moore, even with the tepid support of the president, (which could have hurt him more than helped him) when Mr. Trump claimed to not support Moore, but was MORE opposed to Jones. As the evidence of Moore's proclivities mounts, it is likely that the Republican voters will sit this election out, rather than violate their loyalty to the party and vote for the Democrat. That opens the way for Jones to win with a narrow majority on what was already a special election with a projected low voter turnout.

Trump is backing Moore in the name of the tax cuts, giving Republicans cover to vote for Moore holding their nose. Besides, there is still the possibility that Moore might be expelled from the Senate. although the talk about this has subsided. So moderate Republicans may still vote for Moore, hoping for the best of both worlds - Moore to be expelled, and the seat to remain Republican. In a tight race, stories like this should tip the scale.

The Republican candidate, Judge Roy Moore, will not win the Senate seat.  Democrat Doug Jones will win the seat.  The reasons are low voter turnout, arithmetic, GOP stupidity, and people of color adding to voter turnout.

thanks @Gibson --- guess I'm going back and forth thinking that with the newspapers encouraging rejection of Moore, plus polls lately (which I agree are hard to believe)... Raising by 5%, considering that liberals are also now caught up in the wave of new/old accusations against men (Al Franken, Glenn Thrush, Bill Clinton [revisited, of course]). That may push reluctant voters in the South more towards Moore, with the logic being that the liberals are just as bad or even worse, similar to the narrative currently being pushed over at Breitbart. Also, one voter in Alabama framed the decision as choosing between a pedophile and someone who believes in abortion. That kind of equivalency, similar to the thinking found in the 2016 presidential election, has a good chance of keeping Alabama red.

This election is still rather far away and many more things could happen between now and then. however this is (as all elections are) LOCAL and I think Moore could “shoot someone on Fifth Ave” to mix a Trump metaphor, and still get elected. There has been a recent spate of op-eds calling for a "reckoning" regarding the allegations against Bill Clinton twenty years ago. These op-eds are probably motivated - at least to some degree - by a fear that having defended Clinton, the Democratic Party as an institution lacks credibility when calling for Moore's defeat or disgrace.

As the polling has shown that Moore is losing ground, I've become less confident in this. However, I still don't fully trust the pollls, especially in this situation. After all, if asked if you support a candidate who has been accused of sexually assaulting minors, would you say "yes" aloud, even if you do? Or would you say you're undecided, even though you might be completely decided? This was a phenomenon with Trump, where polls didn't accurately reflect how much support he had because people, for whatever reason, did not articulate that support for pollsters. I wouldn't be surprised to see the same factors at work here, especially in a deep-red state that views Dems on par with Satan.

If they do, will Democrats and Jones supporters rally enough votes to overcome a low Republican turnout or split vote?

Gloria Allred wants the Senate Judiciary committee to permit the accuser to testify before them, and for the Committee to subpoena Moore to testify as well. Allred said that if the Judiciary Committee doesn't act in the next two weeks, the accuser will make a statement under oath elsewhere. Allred also said that the accuser doesn't seek criminal or civil satisfaction, but what Allred characterized as "political satisfaction."

Starting at 100% on this one. The Post's publication of the accusations against Moore will quite possibly have no effect on the election, even if that are proven to be true (which for all I know, they are). The Post probably thinks these accusations will be considered disqualifying by religious people. Nothing could be further from the truth. The type of religious people who are going to vote for Moore believe in a theology of redemption, and that all humans are by nature sinners. The important thing is not Moore's past sins, but his current acceptance of Jesus. To think these accusations, by themselves, would be considered disqualifying by religious people in Alabama is to completely misunderstand Christian theology as it is preached among evangelicals and fundamentalists. Moore is accused of engaging in inappropriate conduct with underage girls, and one instance of sexual abuse because the girl was under the age of consent. This is a serious matter, but it would almost certainly not be regarded as worse than what tens of thousands of his voters had done before they were "saved." This is the whole point of becoming "saved;" to a religious voter in Alabama, of course Moore was a sleazeball before he was saved. So was everybody else. To believers in this type of Christian theology, you can't judge people for their past sins, because everyone would be found wanting. What matters to them is his current faith. The validity of the theology itself is irrelevant; this is the reality of how a great many voters are going to see this.

Starting relatively high. We'll see how the accusations against Moore affect his polling, but right now the GOP is continuing to support him (as much as they can at arm's length). If the accusations begin to affect his public image significantly, it might open the window for the Dem candidate to take the win.
